revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=March 2013}} The following '''list of cats [[Cat|breeds]]''' includes only [[Cat|domestic cat]] [[breed]]s and [[Felid hybrid#Domestic cat and hybridization|domestic × wild hybrids]]. The list includes established breeds recognized by various [[Cat registry|cat registries]], new and experimental breeds, [[landraces]] being established as standardized breeds, distinct domestic populations not being actively developed and lapsed (extinct) breeds. [[The International Cat Association|As of 2019, The International Cat Association]] (TICA) recognizes 71 standardized breeds,[http://tica.org/public/breeds.php The International Cat Association - TICA Breed Standards] the [[Cat Fanciers' Association]] (CFA) recognizes 44,[https://web.archive.org/web/20070629034229/http://www.cfa.org/breeds.html Cat Fanciers' Association - CFA Breed Standards] and [[Fédération Internationale Féline]] (FIFe) recognizes 43.[https://web.archive.org/web/20130218232042/http://fifeweb.org/wp/breeds/breeds_prf_stn.php Fédération InternationFéline - FIFe Breed Standards] Inconsistency in breed classification and naming among registries means that an individual animal may be considered different breeds by different registries (though not necessarily eligible for registry in them all, depending on its exact ancestry). For example, TICA's Himalayan is considered a colorpoint variety of the Persian by CFA, while the Javanese (or Colorpoint Longhair) is a color variation of the Balinese in TICA and CFA; both breeds are merged (along with the Colorpoint Shorthair) into a single "mega-breed", the Colourpoint, by the [[World Cat Federation]] (WCF), who have repurposed the name "Javanese" for the [[Oriental Longhair]]. Also, "Colo[u]rpoint Longhair" refers to different breeds in other registries. There are many examples of nomenclatural overlap and differences of this sort. Furthermore, many geographical and cultural names for cat breeds are fanciful selections made by Western breeders to be exotic sounding and bear no relationship to the actual origin of the breeds;{{cite book |last=Somerville |first=Louisa |title=The Ultimate Guide to Cat Breeds |date=2007 |publisher=Chartwell Books |location=Edison, New Jersey |isbn=9780785822646 |page=44 |quote=There is a lot of confusion surrounding the use of this name in the cat world, although it is always used to describe cats of distinctly Oriental type. It has been adopted simply because of the tradition which has grown up for using the names of countries and islands from south-eastern Asian for other Oriental breeds, such as the Siamese and Balinese.}} the Balinese, Javanese, and Himalayan are all examples of this trend. The [[domestic short-haired]] and [[domestic long-haired cat]] types are not breeds, but terms used (with various spellings) in the [[cat fancy]] to describe [[mongrel]] cats of a general type, by coat length, that do not belong to a particular breed. Some registries permit them to be [[Pedigree (animal)|pedigreed]] and they have been used as [[foundation stock]] in the establishment of some breeds. They should not be confused with standardized breeds with similar names, such as British Shorthair and Oriental Longhair.

It is likely that they originated from somewhere in Asia but there is not solid record.}}||Natural||Moderate |Short||Ticked||[[File:Gustav chocolate.jpg|100px|center|alt=Abyssinian]] |- ! scope="row" |[[Aegean cat|Aegean]] |Greece||Natural||Moderate |Semi-long|| Bicolored or tricolored ||[[File:Aegean cat.jpg|100px|center|alt=Aegean]] |- ! '''Manx Longhair''';
'''Longhaired Manx'''{{efn|1=The Cymric is often classed as a long-haired variety of the Manx rather than a separate breed, e.g., as the "Semi-longhair Manx Variant" in the [[Governing Council of the Cat Fancy]] (GCCF)}}''' |United Kingdom (Isle of Man), United States, and Canada {{efn|1=There may be some dispute to the exact origins of the Cymric breed. The specific dominant autosomal gene (M) that causes the manx tail of the Cymric was found in the cats living on the Isle of Man in the Irish Sea. However the breed itself was developed by a Canadian breeder named Blair Wright and an American breeder named Leslie Falteisek in the 1960s from the Isle of Man population.}}||Mutation of the original Manx||Semi-Cobby |Long||All but colorpoint||[[File:Cymric - Norwegian forest cat presentation show Kotka 2009-02-01 IMG 0687.JPG|100px|center|alt=Cymric]] |- ! scope="row" |[[Cyprus cat|Cyprus]] |Cyprus||Natural||Lean and muscular||All||All but colorpoint and mink|||[[File:CyprusShorthair.jpg|100px|center|alt=Cyprus]] |- ! scope="row" |[[Devon Rex]] |United Kingdom (England)||Mutation||Oriental||Rex||All||[[File:Devon Rex Izzy.jpg|100px|center|alt=Devon Rex]] |- ! scope="row" |[[Donskoy cat|Donskoy]] or

The WCF has combined the Himalayan, the Colourpoint Shorthair and the Javanese/Colorpoint Longhair into a single breed, the Colorpoint}} |United States and United Kingdom||Crossbreed: [[Persian cat|Persian]] and [[Siamese cat|Siamese]]||Cobby||Long||Colorpoint||[[File:Chocolate Himlayan.jpg|100px|center|alt=Himalayan or Colorpoint Persian]] |- ! scope="row" |[[Japanese Bobtail]] |Japan{{efn|1=Due to artefacts and prints dating from as early as the 11th century found in many eastern countries, there is some likelihood these cats may have originated in China, then Japan. However, the first known importation of Japanese Bobtails was from Japan in the 1960s.}}||Natural, mutation||Moderate||Short/long||All but colorpoint and ticked||[[File:JapaneseBobtailBlueEyedMi-ke.JPG|100px|center|alt=Japanese Bobtail]] |- ! scope="row" |[[Javanese cat|Javanese]] or

The WCF has also merged the colorpointed Javanese/Colorpoint Longhair, the Himalayan and the Colourpoint Shorthair of other registries into a single breed, the Colourpoint.
